articles.summary: Belgium's economy and national security will be compromised if the country doesn't take additional climate measures, according to the Belgian government's report. The report was prepared by the Brussels-based Centre for International Policy Studies (CIFPS).

articles.title: Moore: Bill Gates got mugged by reality
articles.author: Boston Herald
articles.summary: Microsoft founder Bill Gates has changed his mind about climate change. For decades, Gates poured billions of dollars into climate change research and mitigation projects. He is one of the richest people to ever walk the planet and is no longer a supporter of climate change initiatives.

articles.title: Highland Papua on alert for extreme weather: BMKG
articles.author: Translator: Yudhi Efendi
articles.summary: The Meteorology, Climatology and Geophysics Agency (BMKG) has urged residents in eight districts of Highland Papua Province to be vigilant against extreme weather. The area is in a seasonal zone and the peak rainy season will occur in December 2025 to January-February 2026.

articles.title: Miami (FL) plays Bethune-Cookman in non-conference showdown
articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.summary: Bethune-Cookman Wildcats (0-1) play Miami Hurricanes (1-0) in a non-conference game in Coral Gables, Florida on Thursday at 11 a.m. EST. Miami (FL) went 14-15 overall last season and 10-7 at home during the 2024-25 season. The Wildcats went 2-14 on the road last season.

articles.title: Statement From The Global Climate And Health Alliance Regarding Bill Gates Commentary And Responses To It
articles.author: Health Alliance
articles.summary: Dr Jeni Miller is the Executive Director of of the Global Climate and Health Alliance. She responded to the recent commentary by Bill Gates and the reactions that followed. Dr Miller believes that tackling the multiple aspects of the climate crisis at the same time is essential to protecting human health.

articles.title: Venice, London, Miami at risk: Scientists name cities that may be submerged soon
articles.author: Oksana Pysarenko
articles.summary: A new study by scientists from Sorbonne University warns of catastrophic and irreversible consequences for the world's coastal cities. In less than 300 years, dozens of cities in the US, the UK, and across Europe could disappear from the face of the Earth. If greenhouse gas emissions remain high, up to 59% of Antarctica's ice shelves could collapse by the year 2300. If emissions are high and reach 12 degrees, 38 ice shelves will be at risk and the sea level could rise by up to 10 meters.

articles.title: Cleaner air may be causing the Earth to warm faster: Study
articles.summary: As pollution decreases, clouds become less reflective, allowing more sunlight to reach the planet's surface. Reduced aerosols improve air quality and health, but they diminish the cooling effect that once masked greenhouse gas warming, complicating the global climate picture. Study published in Nature Communications.

articles.title: Flood warnings in place for Kent coastline including St Margaret's at Cliffe, Sandgate, Sheppey, and Whitstable
articles.author: Charlotte Phillips
articles.summary: Flood warnings have been issued for parts of Kent. The Environment Agency advises people to avoid coastal roads today (November 6). The alerts are in place for the coast between St Margaret's at Cliffe to Sandgate, and for Whitstable, Margate, Dartford, Allhallows, Sheppey, Kemsley, Seasalter and the Medway estuary.

articles.title: How Cleaner Air Could Be Making the Planet Heat Up More Quickly
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: As air pollution has decreased, clouds have become less reflective, making them less effective at cooling the planet. The Pacific and Atlantic Oceans became 3% less reflective each decade between 2003 and 2022. About 70% of this decrease in reflectivity is linked to aerosols, tiny particles that play a major role in cloud formation.

articles.title: What can we expect from the weather this summer?
articles.author: Tom Hartley
articles.summary: Extreme weather is not uncommon in Australia and is likely to become more so as climate change impacts the world around us. Tom Hartley asked the experts what can we expect as we edge closer to summer and asks the experts: what can be expected?

articles.title: Planet in Peril: 30 Years of Climate Talks in Six Charts
articles.summary: The data charting progress in the fight against global warming tells a sobering story. Leaders gather for the U.N. climate summit in Brazil this month. It's been three decades since the world's first annual climate conference took place in the United Nations.

articles.title: Global Climate Crisis: Diplomacy at a Crossroads
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The U.N. climate summit in Brazil draws attention to three decades of efforts in battling global warming. Greenhouse gas emissions have increased by a third since the first meeting. Fossil fuel consumption is growing and temperatures are threatening catastrophic impact. The situation raises questions about the effectiveness of global climate diplomacy.

articles.title: Did Bill Gates really say we don't need to address climate change?
articles.author: Nicole Mortillaro
articles.summary: The Microsoft co-founder and philanthropist, Bill Gates, wrote a controversial memo on climate change. It was posted on his GatesNotes site ahead of the upcoming COP30 climate conference. It came on the day that Jamaica was hit by a powerful Category 5 hurricane. It has sent climate scientists reeling, while skeptics claimed victory.

articles.title: Scientists sound alarm over climate ‘tipping points' ahead of COP30
articles.author: Swissinfo
articles.summary: There is a widespread, irreversible die-off of tropical coral reefs. The Earth has reached its first climate tipping point. Scientists warn that others may soon follow, from melting ice sheets to rainforest collapse. Delegates prepare for the "points of no return"

articles.title: From Green to Brown: How Rising Heat Is Turning the World's Continents to Dust
articles.author: Co E-EDP
articles.summary: As the atmosphere warms, it extracts moisture from land faster than it can be replenished, leading to a steady expansion of drylands across continents. The consequences are devastating. Expanding drylands erode biodiversity, with wetlands turning saline and forests retreating. Agricultural yields are plummeting across Africa, South Asia, and Latin America. Hydropower production is faltering as reservoirs shrink, while thermal plants struggle with cooling-water shortages.

articles.title: Adapting for Tomorrow: Rethinking Resilience in an Era of Global Climate Crisis
articles.author: Co E-EDP
articles.summary: The report 'Rethinking Resilience: Adapting to a Changing Climate' was developed by the World Resources Institute, Stockholm Environment Institute, and the International Institute for Environment and Development. It is a reassessment of how humanity must respond to a rapidly warming world. The poorest and most marginalized people bear the heaviest burdens. Traditional resilience frameworks focus too heavily on rebuilding after disasters rather than preparing for the next one.

articles.title: From Rio to Belem, the poor bear brunt of warming planet
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: Luis Cassiano lives in the Arara neighborhood in northern Rio. He installed a green roof about a decade ago to keep his house up to 15 degrees Celsius cooler than his neighbor's. People in poverty are more vulnerable to climate change and are less likely to have the resources to cope with it than people in wealthier places. UNDP: Even in highly developed countries, 82% of people living in poverty will be exposed to at least one of four climate hazards: high heat, drought, floods and air pollution.

articles.title: Cyclone threat: Elevated risk for NZ as Aus braces for volatile season
articles.author: Newstalk ZB
articles.summary: Australians are bracing for a volatile cyclone season driven by record-breaking ocean temperatures. Tropical cyclones can intensify with higher ocean temperatures, according to the Tropical Cyclone Outlook released last month. The same threat could be heading across the ditch to New Zealand.

articles.title: How Do You Give Expert Advice in Transformational Times?
articles.author: Robert Lempert
articles.summary: Robert Lempert is a policy analyst who provides expert information to decision-makers and the public to improve public policy. He believes that transformational change makes it harder for experts to make good predictions about the future of society. He proposes a change in the way experts frame their task to focus on informing good decisions rather than making predictions.

articles.title: Scientists sound alarm over climate ‘tipping points' ahead of COP30
articles.author: Simon Bradley
articles.summary: In the last two years, heatwaves affected 84% of the world's coral reefs. The Amazon rainforest is closer than previously thought to its tipping point. Greenland and the West Antarctic ice sheets are also close to their tipping points. The AMOC, which drives ocean circulation and stabilises Europe's climate, could collapse if warming exceeds 2°C.

articles.title: UN Chief Rages Against Dying Of Climate Alarm Light
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres is hosting the UN's annual climate conference, COP30, in Belem, Brazil on Nov. 10. He wants all governments to arrive with concrete plans to cut their own emissions over the next decade. President Donald Trump will not be sending an official U.S. delegation to the conference.

articles.title: UN warns global climate goals slipping out of reach
articles.author: SHARON NAKOLA
articles.summary: According to the UN Environment Programme, the planet is still on course for up to 2.8 degrees Celsius of warming this century despite a decade of commitments under the Paris Agreement. UNEP data showed that global greenhouse gas emissions rose 2.3 percent in 2024 to reach a record 58 billion metric tons of carbon-dioxide equivalent. The 20 most advanced and emerging economies accounted for 77 percent of those emissions, while the least-developed countries in Africa contributed only 3 percent.

articles.title: Climate change boosted Hurricane Melissa's destructive winds and rain, analysis finds
articles.summary: Melissa was one of the strongest Atlantic hurricanes to make landfall. It brought destructive weather to Jamaica, Haiti, Dominican Republic and Cuba, causing dozens of deaths across the Caribbean. Climate change boosted the destructive winds and rain unleashed by Hurricane Melissa, according to an analysis released Thursday.

articles.title: Climate change boosted Hurricane Melissa's destructive winds and rain, analysis finds
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa flooded Petit-Goave, Haiti, Oct. 30, 2025, because of the storm. The damage was caused by a storm surge caused by the storm Melissa. The article is available for free to subscribers. Gift this article to your friends and family for free.

articles.title: Climate change boosted Hurricane Melissa's destructive winds and rain, analysis finds
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change boosted the destructive winds and rain unleashed by Hurricane Melissa and increased the temperatures and humidity that fueled the storm, according to an analysis released Thursday. The analysis was based on data from the U.S. National Center for Atmospheric Research.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa Devastates The Caribbean As The UN Distributes Lifesaving Aid
articles.author: Oritro Karim
articles.summary: In late October, Hurricane Melissa made landfall in the Caribbean, causing catastrophic damage to civilian infrastructure and a devastating loss of life. At least 84 civilian deaths have been reported, 43 in Haiti, 35 in Jamaica and 1.6 million children are at risk of the impacts of flooding, landslides, and regional disruption. The UN estimates that roughly 6 million people have been affected by Hurricane Melissa. The World Food Programme launched an emergency response plan for the hardest hit communities in Jamaica. UN agencies mobilized critical support services prior to Hurricane Melissa's landfall in Cuba.

articles.title: Could Sicily become europe's next desert due to climate change?  Vantage on Firstpost
articles.author: Palki Sharma
articles.summary: Sicily is experiencing more frequent climate emergencies due to climate change. The island's temperature has increased by over two degrees Celsius. In 2024, authorities declared a state of emergency after drought affected 90 towns and 800,000 residents. Experts attribute a 50 percent higher chance of droughts to human-caused warming. Sicily is increasingly being seen as Europe's potential next desert.

articles.title: Momentum on climate action is waning, Singapore minister says as COP30 looms
articles.author: The Star
articles.summary: Momentum on global climate action is waning as geopolitical issues pile up, according to analysts.   Â   in Singapore, the world community's opinion on climate change is waning. In the U.S. it's more positive.  in China.

articles.title: The Southern Ocean is holding in a ‘burp'
articles.author: Devika Rao
articles.summary: In the future, heat from the Southern Ocean could be released into the atmosphere and cause climate change-like effects. The longer humans continue to release emissions, the more heat will be trapped in the ocean. This release would occur after centuries of net negative emissions levels and gradual global cooling. It could lead to a 'decadal- to centennial-scale period of warming. The released heat will not be distributed evenly around the world.

articles.title: Turbulence in oceans to increase rapidly as Earth heats up
articles.summary: The polar oceans will become more turbulent as the planet warms, according to a new study by the Institute for Basic Science in South Korea. The process of 'mesoscale horizontal stirring' (MHS) will increase in both the Arctic and Southern Oceans as sea ice disappears. MHS involves the stretching and mixing of seawater by winds and ocean currents. As sea ice retreats, the energy input and density changes boost this stirring, which influences how heat, nutrients, fish larvae and pollutants move across the ocean.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa death toll reaches 75 across Haiti and Jamaica
articles.author: Elif Şanlı
articles.summary: The death toll from Hurricane Melissa's path through the Caribbean has risen to 75 across Haiti and Jamaica. The powerful storm system has caused catastrophic flooding and landslides, destroying homes, damaging critical infrastructure, and creating a severe humanitarian crisis. Haiti's Civil Protection Directorate reports 43 deaths, with at least seven people still missing. In Cuba, UN assessments indicate approximately 2.2 million people were affected, with damage to 60,000 homes, 461 health centers, and 1,552 schools.

articles.title: Đắk Lắk issues fishing ban and allows students to stay home in response to Storm No. 13

articles.author: Aryan Rai

The BMJ's special climate issue highlights several legal cases where medical data has shaped rulings. In the UK, the death of nine-year-old Ella Adoo-Kissi-Debrah became a landmark case after an inquest found that air pollution contributed to her death. In Italy, the European Court of Human Rights used peer-reviewed evidence.

articles.title: Greenland Continues To Defy Alarmist Warming And Ice Melt Narratives
articles.author: Kenneth Richard
articles.summary: Greenland temperature stations indicate there was an abrupt 2.9°C warming trend from 1922-1932. The warming trend was almost identical to the 3.1°C trend from 1993-2007. Between the two warming periods (WP1 and WP2), there was a 3°C cooling trend from 1933-1992.

It worsened the hurricane due to climate change. It was worse than Hurricane Melissa in terms of sea level rise. It got worse because of global warming, too.

articles.title: 1.5C Warming Still Possible, Climate Study Finds
articles.summary: The world has exceeded the 1.5°C threshold for two years running. New report from Climate Analytics suggests a pathway to peak warming at 1.7°C before 2050. Global emissions need to fall by roughly 20% by 2030 and by 11% annually throughout the 2030s to limit warming to 1.6°C. Methane emissions must be cut by 30% by 2035. The Cop30 UN climate summit is taking place in Belém, Brazil.

articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: The health of billions living in India and around the world is at risk due to a worsening climate crisis. Heat-related deaths have surged 23 per cent since the 1990s, to roughly 546,000 deaths a year globally. Outdoor air pollution from fossil-fuel use caused over 17 lakh deaths in India in 2022.

Australia's failure to act on climate change is compounded by the insult of exporting gas overseas without payment. Australia has kicked the climate can down the road for too long.

China is the biggest emitter globally, followed by the US and Russia. India added 165 million tonnes of greenhouse gases during 2023-24. India's per capita emissions are the lowest among the major economies. Only a third of countries linked to the Paris Agreement submitted new NDCs within the September 30 deadline.

articles.title: Experts Warn: Climate Change and Conflict Drive Major Health Risks

Conflict has been responsible for staggering mortality rates among children, claiming over ten million young lives since 1995. Women in reproductive age living in zones of intense conflict experience mortality rates triple that of their counterparts in peaceful settings. The political economy of war constrains environmental governance, thereby impeding climate-related health interventions.

articles.title: UN: 'Virtually impossible' to achieve 1.5C climate target
articles.author: RTE
articles.summary: This year is on track to be the second or third warmest globally, according to UN scientists. Global average surface temperatures in January to August 2025 were 1.42C above pre-industrial levels. A slight drop is still possible and essential, the WMO says.

articles.title: How the US cut climate-changing emissions while its economy more than doubled
articles.author: San Francisco Chronicle
articles.summary: Valerie Thomas is a professor at Georgia Institute of Technology. She says countries have been discussing the need to rein in climate change for three decades, yet global greenhouse gas emissions are still rising. The Conversation is an independent and nonprofit source of news, analysis and commentary from academic experts.

articles.title: Did Bill Gates really say we don't need to address climate change?
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Microsoft co-founder and philanthropist Bill Gates has been in the news recently with claims that he has changed his stance on climate change following a memo he posted on his website. But is it really the case that he's changed his mind on this matter?

articles.title: Brazil's Lula calls for roadmap to combat global warming at COP30
articles.author: Syrian Arab News Agency
articles.summary: Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva warned that the window for effective action to confront the impacts of global warming is about to close. UN Secretary-General António Guterres described the failure to limit global temperature rise as 'deadly negligence'

articles.author: The Miami Herald
articles.summary: Human-caused climate change is linked to stronger, wetter hurricanes, according to the IPCC.   Â. Â   yer.  yest, yest, yest. Yest, sest, iest, eest.

articles.title: Highlighting Rapidly Growing Links between Climate and Conflict, Security Council Emphasizes Need to Boost International Support, Increase Financing (United Nations Security Council)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Climate change exacerbates conflict-causing tension, which leads to pollution and ecosystem damage, the Security Council heard today. "Imagine a mother living in one of the most vulnerable neighbourhoods" of Haiti's capital, Maranatha, the council was told.

articles.title: Global warming made Hurricane Melissa more damaging, researchers say
articles.author: Bennington Banner
articles.summary: Melissa's path through the Caribbean last month was made more violent by climate change, according to a scientific analysis released Thursday. The analysis was based on a study by the University of California, Santa Barbara.      Â   .

articles.title: Antarctica's collapse may already be unstoppable, scientists warn
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: Antarctica is undergoing abrupt changes that could trigger global consequences, according to researchers. The changes include melting ice, collapsing ice and melting of glaciers.    "Antarctic is experiencing abrupt changes and could have global consequences."

articles.title: Challenges and Cheers for Bill Gates on Climate Change
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Readers respond to news and opinion articles about Bill Gates's public memo on climate change. Also: Interfaith connections; the myth of originalism.    .   i   in the comments section below the article that you responded to.  In the meantime, read the article.

articles.title: 'Moral failure': Leaders seek to rally world at Amazon climate talks
articles.author: The Greeneville Sun
articles.summary: Fears of a fracturing global resolve loomed over climate talks in the Brazilian Amazon on Thursday. World leaders acknowledged their failure to contain global warming to agreed limits, as they are at the talks in Brazil.       .  .

articles.title: Indian cities vulnerable to climate shocks, warns new study
articles.author: India Today
articles.summary: Indian cities are vulnerable to climate shocks, according to a new study by the Centre for International Policy Studies (CIFS) and the World Resources Institute (WRI).       .   for more information, visit the CIFS website here.

articles.title: Climate change to severely impact Belgium's economy, security: Report
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Belgium's economy, public health and national security face mounting threats from climate change unless the country urgently steps up adaptation measures, according to a major risk assessment released Thursday by the climate institute Cerac. "The question is no longer if climate disasters will happen, but when and how we will respond," says the assessment.

articles.title: UN chief admits world has 'failed' on 1.5°C limit, overshoot inevitable by early 2030s
articles.author: Anadolu Agency
articles.summary: Antonio Guterres says the world has failed to prevent global temperatures from breaching the critical 1.5 degrees Celsius (2.7 degrees Fahrenheit) threshold. He warns a temporary overshoot is now inevitable and warns that the hard truth is that we have failed to ensure we remain below 1:5 degrees.
